feed.title: Combined summary - Rethinking “Incentive Compatibility” Within the Bitcoin Protocol

entry.title: Combined summary - Rethinking “Incentive Compatibility” Within the Bitcoin Protocol
entry.summary: The email thread between John Carvalho and Michael Folkson revolves around the concept of incentive-compatibility in relation to Bitcoin's mempoolfullrbf feature. Carvalho argues that a single transaction cannot be incentive-compatible by merely restricting it to a higher fee or fee rate, as RBF is inherently a fee-minimization tool that conflicts with extra-mempool behaviors resulting in more transactions per block or lifetime. He proposes user-compatible designs that allow users to signal intent and desired behavior rather than having a mempool that overrides all intent with RBF.In contrast, Folkson defends the role of P2P/mempool/policy protocol developers in setting defaults and ensuring network health, recommending further reading for Carvalho. He explains that their job is to ensure anyone can effectively propagate a consensus valid transaction across the network without harming network health and give higher layers built on top of the Bitcoin network the best chance to succeed.The discussion also touches upon the use of RBF as a fee-minimization tool and its potential conflict with miners' desire to maximize fees per block and lifetime. Both parties have differing perspectives on the issue, with Carvalho suggesting alternative designs that give users flexibility and allow market incentives to dictate hashpower, while Folkson defends the trade-offs involved in policy defaults and delegates responsibility to those who have worked full time in this area for years.Overall, the email exchange highlights the importance of understanding the dynamics and trade-offs involved in Bitcoin transactions and the need for active management and questioning of Bitcoin software changes.
